string_data:
Greta Thunberg laughed and wiped her eyes in court on Thursday as she went on trial accused of disrupting business leaders trying to develop "sustainable solutions to the world's energy challenges".

The Swedish climate activist, 21, is charged with a public order offence after being arrested while protesting outside a gathering of fossil fuel executives in central London last year.

Thunberg, two Fossil Free London (FFL) protesters and two Greenpeace activists appeared at Westminster magistrates' court for the start of a two-day trial after each pleaded not guilty in November to breaching Section 14 of the Public Order Act 1986. If found guilty they face fines of up to Â£2,500.

The court heard how she had been given a "final warning" by police to move to a designated protest area before being arrested outside the InterContinental Hotel in Mayfair on October 17.

Luke Staton, prosecuting, said leaders from the energy, finance and business worlds were present at the Energy Intelligence Forum, whose "stated aim" was to develop "sustainable solutions to the world's energy challenges", prompting laughter from Thunberg and the other defendants. Critics have dubbed the event the "oily money conference".

The court heard that protesters started to gather at around 7.30am and police engaged with them about improving access for about 1,000 people inside the hotel, which had been made "impossible".

Staton said some protesters gained access to the roof just before 10.30am and "were slowly abseiling down the side of the building".

Superintendent Matthew Cox said a group of around ten drummers were generating "quite a deafening noise" and that other protesters were letting off smoke flares.

At 12.30pm he decided to impose a section 14 condition, which dictated that the protest could continue but on the pavement to the south of the hotel.

Thunberg was standing outside the hotel entrance when given a "final warning" but "said that she was staying where she was and so she was arrested," Staton said.
